questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with sudden hives, facial swelling, and difficulty breathing shortly after eating shrimp at a restaurant. She reports similar reactions in the past. She appears anxious, with pronounced facial swelling and wheezing. Which sequence correctly describes the immunological events in this type of reaction?

choices.text: Allergen exposure → Mast cell activation → IgE production → Th2 cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators
Th2 cell activation → Allergen exposure → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators
Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators
Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → Mast cell activation → IgE production → Release of inflammatory mediators

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators

Explanation:

The given scenario is an example of anaphylaxis following shrimp intake, which is an example of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

Step 1: First Exposure (Sensitization phase)

  • Allergen enters the body.

  • Naive CD4+ T-cells → differentiate into TH2 cells.

  • TH2 cells release cytokines:

    • IL-4 → stimulates B-cells to class switch and produce IgE.

    • IL-5 → activates eosinophils.

    • IL-13 → enhances IgE production and mucus secretion.

  • IgE antibodies bind to FCERI receptors on mast cells (mast cells now become sensitized).

Step 2: Second Exposure (Effector phase)

  • Allergen re-enters the body.

  • It binds to IgE already attached on mast cells.

  • This causes cross-linking (polymerization) of IgE molecules.

  • Cross-linking triggers mast cell degranulation.

  • Mast cells release mediators:

    • Histamine → vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, itching, bronchospasm.

    • Leukotrienes & Prostaglandins → prolonged inflammation.

    • Cytokines → recruit more immune cells

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional Th2 cells in type I hypersensitivity reactions?

choices.text: IL-4
IL-5
IL-13
IL-10

questions.solution:
Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5 (Option B)

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13 (Option C)
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10 (Option D)
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of allergic asthma presents with worsening respiratory symptoms. The sputum sample shows the presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with this phase of hypersensitivity reaction?

choices.text: Recruitment of eosinophils to the site of inflammation by chemokines like eotaxin
Production of IL-5 by Th2 cells to activate eosinophils
Release of histamine and tryptase by eosinophils
Liberation of major basic protein and eosinophil cationic protein by activated eosinophils

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Release of histamine and tryptase by eosinophils

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given scenario suggests that the patient's presentation involves eosinophils, particularly the identification of Charcot-Leyden crystals (composed of galectin-10 protein) in the extracellular space, which is derived from eosinophils. (suggestive of delayed phase of type 1 HSR).
  • Histamine and tryptase are preformed mediators released by mast cells during the early phase of Type I hypersensitivity (Option B), not by eosinophils in the late phase.
 

Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin)

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach
  • Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.
  • Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?

choices.text: Graft rejection
Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis
Casoni test
P-K reactions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Graft rejection

Explanation:

Graft rejection is not an example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

  • Acute graft rejection involves Type II and Type IV hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Hyperacute graft rejection involves Type II hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Chronic graft rejection involves Type IV hypersensitivity reactions.

Examples of Type I hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Allergic conditions include Allergic rhinitis, Allergic dermatitis, Allergic conjunctivitis, or Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (Option B).
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Casoni test: Done for detection of Echinococcus granulosus (Hydatid cyst) (Option C).
  • Drug reactions
  • P-K reactions (Option D) The PK reaction is a laboratory technique used to demonstrate type I hypersensitivity, which involves IgE antibodies and mast cell degranulation, often leading to immediate allergic reactions.
  • Theobald Smith phenomenon.(Theobald Smith phenomenon is the term for the development of hypersensitivity to bacteria in animals after repeated injections)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not an example of a Type II hypersensitivity reaction?

choices.text: Rheumatic fever
Multiple sclerosis
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
Pernicious anaemia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multiple sclerosis

Explanation:

Multiple sclerosis is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, not type II.

Examples of Type II hypersensitivity reactions are: 

Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive

My

Myasthenia Gravis

Blood

Blood transfusion reaction

Group

Good pasture syndrome,

Graves disease

Is

Immune hemolytic anaemia,

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

R

Rh incompatibility,

Rheumatic fever

H

Hyperacute transplant rejection

Positive

Pemphigus (Bullous),

Pernicious Anemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pernicious anaemia is incorrect?

choices.text: Natural Killer (NK) cells participate in Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.
Opsonisation involves IgG antibodies coating cells, enhancing phagocytosis via Fc receptors.
When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis.
Myasthenia gravis is an example of antibody-mediated cell surface receptor dysfunction.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis.

Explanation:

In pernicious anaemia, the type of hypersensitivity involved is Type II hypersensitivity, also known as antibody-mediated hypersensitivity. This type of hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to antigens on host cells, leading to cell destruction or dysfunction.

Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis
(Option B)

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
(Option C)

Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage.

  • Goodpasture syndrome

  • Acute rheumatic fever

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
(Option A)

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.

  • Pernicious anemia

  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)
(Option D)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).

  • Graves disease

  • Myasthenia gravis

Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis
(Option B)

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
(Option C)

Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage.

  • Goodpasture syndrome

  • Acute rheumatic fever

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
(Option A)

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.

  • Pernicious anemia

  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)
(Option D)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).

  • Graves disease

  • Myasthenia gravis

Note: Myasthenia gravis and Graves disease are now classified as Type V hypersensitivity (Type V > Type II)
Type V hypersensitivity reaction: Antibodies against cellular receptors.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with swelling in his face and legs, decreased urine output, and dark-colored urine. His parents reported that he had a sore throat about three weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Type I hypersensitivity
Type II hypersensitivity
Type III hypersensitivity
Type IV hypersensitivity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III hypersensitivity

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a classic example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. PSGN is an immune complex-mediated disease caused by the deposition of circulating immune complexes (composed of streptococcal antigens and antibodies) in the kidney glomeruli, leading to inflammation and damage.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity: (mnemonic- SHARP)

  • Serum sickness, Schick test, SLE (Hematological lesion)
  • Henoch Schonlein purpura
  • Arthus reaction
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)

questions.text: Which of the following is typically associated with localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity?

choices.text: Serum sickness
Arthus reaction
Membranous glomerulonephritis
Reactive arthritis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arthus reaction

Explanation:

The presentation from the given clinical scenario suggests localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity or Type III hypersensitivity reaction.

  • The “Arthus reaction” is localized tissue necrosis caused by acute immune complex vasculitis, often occurring in the skin.
  • It occurs when pre-existing antibodies (IgG) interact with antigens locally injected into the skin or other tissues, leading to complement activation, inflammation, and tissue damage.
  • This reaction is typically seen in response to repeated exposure to certain antigens (e.g., vaccines) and results in a localised inflammatory response such as localised swelling, redness, pain, and tissue destruction.

Systemic type III hypersensitivity

Localised type III hypersensitivity

Involves the widespread formation of immune complexes in circulation and can deposit in various tissues and organs throughout the body, including the kidneys (leading to glomerulonephritis), joints, skin, blood vessels, and other sites. (e.g., in chronic infections or autoimmune diseases).

Immune complexes are deposited at specific sites of antigen exposure, such as the skin (as in the Arthus reaction) or joint spaces, leading to local inflammation (localized swelling, redness, pain) and tissue damage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice and fatigue, recently diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Further investigation reveals abnormal liver function tests, indicating hepatic injury. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of hypersensitivity involved in this case is true?

choices.text: CD8+ T cells differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells upon antigen exposure
CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th2 cells upon exposure to antigen
Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway
Perforin-granzyme-dependent killing is a mechanism employed by CD4+ T cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas- Fas ligand pathway.

Explanation:

The type of hypersensitivity involved in hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is Type IV.

Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)

CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells (Options A and B ruled out).

Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis. Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)


 

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection. CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing (Option D ruled out) and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells. (Option C)
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. The physician suspects a TB infection and performs a tuberculin skin test. Which of the following is not an example of the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this test?

choices.text: Contact dermatitis from poison ivy exposure.
Rheumatoid arthritis.
Crohn's disease.
Reactive arthritis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reactive arthritis.

Explanation:

The tuberculin skin test (TST) mentioned in the scenario represents Delayed type hypersensitivity (Type IV hypersensitivity).
Reactive arthritis, on the other hand, shows Type III hypersensitivity.

Examples of Type IV hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Contact dermatitis from exposure to
    • Urushiol from poison ivy or poison oak
    • Detergent
    • Artificial jewellery (Ni and Cd)
  • Granuloma
  • Mantoux test
  • Lepromin test
  • Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn’s disease)
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Type IV > Type III hypersensitivity)
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Type V hypersensitivity?

choices.text: Antibodies bind to cell surface receptors, leading to altered cellular function
Immune complexes form and deposit in tissues, triggering localized inflammation and damage.
Antibodies target cell surface antigens, resulting in complement activation and cell destruction.
IgE antibodies mediate the release of histamine from mast cells, causing immediate allergic reactions.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Antibodies bind to cell surface receptors, leading to altered cellular function

Explanation:

Type V hypersensitivity:

  • Involves IgG antibodies binding to cell surface receptors, altering the normal function of those cells.
  • The antibodies may mimic hormones or block receptor function
  • Leads to altered cellular activity without direct destruction of the cells.
  • It can cause overstimulation or inhibition of normal cellular functions.
    • Graves' disease: Antibodies stimulate the thyroid hormone receptor, causing hyperthyroidism.
    • Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies block acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness.

IgE antibodies mediate the release of histamine from mast cells, causing immediate allergic reactions (Option B) is a hallmark of Type I hypersensitivity, involving immediate reactions and allergic responses mediated by IgE.

Immune complexes form and deposit in tissues, triggering localized inflammation and damage (Option C) describes Type III hypersensitivity, which involves immune complex deposition leading to inflammation.

Antibodies target cell surface antigens, resulting in complement activation and cell destruction (Option D) is characteristic of Type II hypersensitivity, where antibody binding leads to direct cell damage through complement activation.

questions.text: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the phases of pathogenesis in Type III hypersensitivity?

choices.text: Formation of immune complexes → Inflammation and tissue injury → Deposition in blood vessels.
Deposition of immune complexes → Formation of antibodies → Tissue injury and inflammation.
Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.
Antibody production → Immune complex formation → Activation of cytotoxic T cells.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.

Explanation:

Phases of Type 3 hypersensitivity:

1. Formation of Immune Complexes:

  • After introducing a protein antigen, antibodies are formed (typically within one week) and react with the antigen in circulation, creating antigen-antibody complexes.

2. Deposition of Immune Complexes:

  • These complexes circulate and are deposited in blood vessels, particularly in organs like the kidneys and joints.
  • Medium-sized complexes formed in slight antigen excess are most pathogenic.

3. Inflammation and Tissue Injury:

  • Deposited immune complexes trigger acute inflammation about 10 days post-antigen exposure, leading to symptoms like fever, joint pain, and proteinuria.
  • Complement activation contributes to tissue injury, with serum C3 levels potentially serving as a marker for disease activity.

Histopathological lesions:

  • Inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis).

Type 3 hypersensitivity (Mnemonic- T SHARP):

  • Type II lepra reaction.
  • SLE.
  • Serum sickness.
  • Henoch Schonlein Purpura.
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • Arthus reaction.
  • Reactive Arthritis.
  • Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa.
  • Parasitic diseases.
